In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Studies carried out by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other development 
partners have documented the spread of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and HIV during 
the implementation of infrastructure projects.1 Roads, in particular, while bringing many benefits, 
increase risks through greater mobility and connectivity.  The investment component of the 
upcoming North Eastern State Roads Investment Program will finance the reconstruction and 
upgrading  of  about  1,000  kilometers  of  state  roads  and  highways  in  north  eastern  states 
between  2010  and  2012.  Consultations  with  government,  civil  society,  and  private  sector 
partners in New Delhi, Assam, Meghalaya, and Nagaland identified the need for (i) ensuring the 
prevention and mitigation of impacts of inherent health, social and gender, and safety risks 
associated  with  infrastructure  development;  (ii)  fostering  tripartite  partnerships  among 
government (state public works departments, state AIDS control societies [SACSs]), civil society 
organizations (CSOs), and the private sector for a more effective and sustainable response to 
the epidemic; and (iii) strengthening the capacity of civil works contractors to comply with the 
provisions  set  by  the  International  Federation  of  Consulting  Engineers  in  the  Multilateral 
Development Banks’ Harmonized General Conditions of Contract for Construction.2 
 
2.  The  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)3 will  be  implemented  in  five 
selected north eastern states (Assam, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Manipur, and Nagaland). TA fact-
finding missions in May–July 2007 at central, state, and district levels and follow-on discussions 
with the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) and the Joint United Nations Programme 
on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) in April 2009 confirmed the relevance of the proposed activities under 
the TA as well as the governments‘ commitment to work with ADB in the implementation of the 
proposed activities.4 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The new 2007 HIV estimates released by NACO, supported by UNAIDS and the World 
Health Organization, indicate that national adult HIV prevalence in India is about 0.34%, which 
corresponds to an estimated 2.3 million Indian adults (15–49 years). State-specific variations in 
the profile of the epidemic have been observed: several states in the north eastern region have 
shown higher HIV prevalence and multiple routes of HIV transmission with diversity between 
and within states. 
 
4.  In the north eastern region, the HIV epidemic has progressed beyond the prototype of 
being driven by injecting drug use, with heterosexual transmission an equally important driver. 
Most of the HIV-related services were concentrated in urban settings, and the geographical 
reach into rural areas was poor. Women with unequal access to health and nutrition and a lower 
level of participation in social and political decision-making processes are particularly at a 
disadvantage, increasing their vulnerability to HIV significantly. Nagaland and Manipur are high-
prevalence states in the north eastern region. Mizoram is highly vulnerable and Meghalaya has

reported a very low number of HIV infections and AIDS cases, but there are indications that it is 
higher. In recognition of the importance of the north eastern region, NACO has established a 
North East Regional Office based in Guwahati (Assam) that is responsible for coordinating 
government  and  development  partners'  interventions.  United  Nations  (UN)  agencies,  with 
financial support from the Australian Agency for International Development and the Swedish 
International Development Cooperation Agency, are implementing a joint UN initiative in the 
north eastern region, coordinated by the UNAIDS Secretariat. 
 
5.  ADB‘s HIV/AIDS strategic directions‘ paper5 acknowledges differences in power relations 
between men and women and the persistence of gender-based discriminatory practices as 
critical factors contributing to the spread of the epidemic. ADB‘s commitment to a multisector 
and gender-responsive approach to HIV interventions—embedded in the strategic directions 
paper—has been reiterated in the Joint Initiative by Development Agencies for the Infrastructure 
Sectors to Mitigate the Spread of HIV/AIDS6 signed by ADB and other development partners in 
2006 and the Operational Plan for Improving Health under Strategy 2020.7 Most recently, ADB‘s 
Strategy 20208 reiterates ADB‘s commitment to the mitigation of HIV risks and impacts in its 
portfolio  by  continuing  to  incorporate  activities  to  control  the  transmission  and  spread  of 
communicable diseases, particularly HIV, in its transport and other infrastructure projects. 
 
6.  The size of the forthcoming road investment program, the reach of its projected adverse 
impacts, and their links to the main engine of HIV transmission in the north eastern region 
require a deliberate and proportionate response from ADB. In this context, addressing the 
needs of women and children—reaching out to far-flung districts by strengthening the network of 
services in partnership with the state machinery as well as other community-based service 
providers—is critical. Crosscutting issues such as capacity building, advocacy, quality systems, 
inter-sector collaboration, and monitoring and evaluation will have to be addressed. 
 
  III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The impact of the TA will be reduced incidence of STIs and HIV among construction 
workers,  sex  workers,  migrant  workers,  and  local  communities  in  the  project  area;  and 
addressing some of the factors that contribute to their vulnerability. Its expected outcome will be 
expanded networks and stronger service delivery capabilities for HIV prevention in five north 
eastern states (Assam, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Manipur, and Nagaland) through public–private 
partnership. The TA will complement the existing effort of NACO in the north eastern region. 
The TA was developed in 2007 in consultation with the Ministry of Development of the north 
eastern region, NACO, relevant state government agencies (public works departments and 
SACSs),  and  CSOs  involved  in  HIV  prevention  in  the  project  area.  The  TA  design  and 
implementation arrangements are informed by the national framework set out in the National 
AIDS Control Programme III (2006–2011) (NACP III)9 and related operational guidelines issued 
by NACO. It reflects lessons learned and good practices in implementing HIV preventive actions 
in the north eastern region.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  The  activities  under  the  TA  components  will  aim  to  (i)  set  a  project  baseline  and 
monitoring and evaluation system (component 1); (ii) assess the institutional framework for HIV 
prevention in the infrastructure sector (component 2); (iii) develop and roll out HIV training and 
skills transfer programs targeting economic operators (component 3); (iv) develop the capacity 
of state civil society organizations and trade unions (component 4); and (v) implement direct 
interventions for HIV prevention (component 5). The TA outputs will include (i) a TA work plan to 
ensure that the TA activities fit with NACP III; (ii) capacity needs assessments; (iii) behavioral 
baseline reports; (iv) situation analyses reports on institutional framework; (v) training tools and 
material; (vi) project impact assessment; (vii) capacity development initiatives of selected state 
government, CSOs, economic operators, and trade unions; (viii) HIV direct interventions; (ix) 
technical report on mitigating the social risks and impacts of road projects in the north eastern 
region; and (x) assessment of TA tripartite partnership modalities. 
 
Component 1: Project Baseline and Monitoring and Evaluation System 
 
9.  This component will support close monitoring of implementation of the TA and regularly 
assess its progress. It will generate insights on the nexus between HIV transmission, road 
construction, and high-risk behavior. A research institute with established capabilities for health 
research will be subcontracted to (i) do baseline mapping and gap analysis of local services at 
the district level,10 subject to the gaps identified in the mapping undertaken by NACO; and 
(ii) develop and carry out a monitoring and evaluation framework for the project. Information 
collected  will  include  (i)  HIV  risk  and  vulnerability  assessment  among  groups  that  will  be 
affected  by  the  infrastructure  operation;  and  (ii)  capacity  needs  assessment  of  economic 
operators,  CSOs,  including  nongovernment  organization  (NGOs),  community-based 
organizations, people living with HIV (PLHIV) organizations, and trade unions in the corridor of 
influence  of  the  project.  Six  monthly  reports  will  be  produced  and  distributed  to  relevant 
stakeholders. The final report will present the key findings of the surveys and provide a review 
of the tripartite partnership modalities. It will identify options for the institutionalization of the 
approach in other states, infrastructure development, and other sector-specific interventions. 
 
Component 2: Institutional Framework for HIV Prevention in the Infrastructure Sector 
 
10.  The component will assess (i) policy commitments to gender and HIV/AIDS at central 
level and their incorporation in state-specific infrastructure sector strategies, master plans, and 
regulatory frameworks for public investments, construction, contractor accreditation, mobile and 
migrant  population,  workplace,  and  labor  environment;  (ii)  existing  government  agencies, 
economic  operators,  and  CSOs  involved  in  HIV  prevention;  (iii) transport  and  construction 
companies‘ and associations‘ response to the epidemic; and (iv) existing arrangements and 
public–private partnership modalities for the mitigation of health and other social risks inherent 
in  infrastructure  development. The situation  analysis  report  will  inform  NACO  and  SACSs‘ 
implementation  of  the  NACP  III  and  interventions  proposed  to  support  infrastructure 
development in the north eastern region. 
 
Component 3: HIV Training and Skills Transfer Programs Targeting Economic Operators 
 
11.  Training sessions will be offered to a core group of economic operators. These include (i) 
the  private  business  sector,  with  its  subgroups—individual  construction  and  transportation 
firms—represented by their chief executive officers and human resources managers; industry 
associations,  trade  unions,  and  business  chambers  representing  the  construction  and 
                                                
10 Existing mapping data will be taken into account and gaps addressed.

4   
 
transportation sectors; (ii) health service (clinic and non-clinic based) providers; and (iii) condom 
manufacturers and distributors. The training sessions will aim at building the capacities of 
contractors to develop and implement workplace health and safety policies and preventive 
interventions in the project site, and promote compliance with the NACP III, national guidelines, 
and  other  applicable  regulations.  Between  training  and  refresher  training  sessions,  trained 
board members and human resources managers of selected companies will provide training for 
their companies‘ employees, subcontractors, and consultants, at their own initiative and cost.11 
 
Component 4: Capacity Development for State Civil Society Organizations and Trade 
Unions 
 
12.  Based on a needs assessment, this component will support a training program for 
capacity  development  of  selected  state  NGOs,  community-based  organizations,  PLHIV 
organizations, and trade unions (up to 10 per state, depending on the results of the needs 
assessment at district level) involved in HIV awareness and behavior change in the project area. 
Indicatively,  the  capacity  development  program  inputs  will  involve  training,  exposure  visits, 
―hand holding‖ or mentoring, and knowledge- and experience-sharing workshops. 
 
Component 5: Direct Interventions for HIV Prevention 
 
13.  This component will address gaps identified in the project area and complement the 
ongoing targeted interventions of SACSs. Direct interventions for HIV prevention (up to 3 per 
state) will be carried out by state CSOs along ADB-financed highways and will be informed by 
NACO‘s standard operational guidelines. All activities will be preceded by a review of existing 
data sources, risk assessment studies and supplemental mapping of hotspots (points of sex 
solicitation), prioritized industry or workforce centers and large residential areas, and preferred 
health  providers.  Activities  will  target  construction  workers  in  the  campsites  and  local 
communities directly affected by the infrastructure operation and may include STI and condom 
services provision within NACP III objectives in the project area. Pilot interventions to test 
effective modalities to promote the economic empowerment of PLHIV—with focus on widows, 
destitute single mothers, women heads of households, and sex workers—may be supported 
through alternative livelihood and self-employment training initiatives, in line with  NACP III 
strategies and linkage with line departments implementing similar programs. 
   
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,770,000. TA fact-finding missions in May–July 
2007 at central, state, and district levels and follow-on discussions with the NACO and UNAIDS 
in April 2009 confirmed the relevance of the proposed activities under the TA as well as the 
governments' commitment to work with ADB in the implementation of the proposed activities.   
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  The cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  NACO will be the executing agency for the TA and NACO‘s North East Regional Office 
(NERO), through the UNAIDS Secretariat in New Delhi, will be the implementing agency. The 
UNAIDS  Secretariat  will  act  as  TA  coordinator  and  be  responsible—in  consultation  with 
UNAIDS Secretariat in New Delhi—for the recruitment of all consulting services under this 
                                                
11 Activities will be extended to existing networks of companies—e.g., Confederation of Indian Industry, Federation of 
Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry, North East Chamber of Commerce, All India Organization of 
Employers, transport sector organizations (e.g., Transport Corporation of India), petroleum-refining companies—
employers‘ and workers‘ organizations, and other allied organizations and structures at the state/district level.

5 
 
project, in accordance with ADB‘s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). The UNAIDS Secretariat will be responsible for the overall coordination of the 
TA activities, supporting the NACO North East Regional Office, mobilizing the expertise of other 
UN partner agencies12 in a timely matter, as needed, and effectively liaising with ADB. It will 
submit a detailed work plan to ADB at project onset—in consultation with NACO and NERO—to 
ensure the consistency of TA activities with the NACP III.  
 
16.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  36  months,  commencing  in  February  2010  with 
completion 3 years later in 2013. Consultants‘ inputs will amount to 39 person-months for 
national consultants, 9 months for a national research institute, 12 months for a national training 
institute; and 120 months for five service delivery NGOs (24 months each, 1 per state). However, 
the specific terms of reference in Appendix 4 will be refined following TA inception. 
 
17.  Detailed implementation arrangements are in Appendix 3. With respect to disbursement, 
funds  to  be  transferred  by  ADB  to  UNDP  shall  be  paid  (para.  9[a],  MOU)  in  semiannual 
installments in advance of the implementation of planned activities with the amount of the 
installment based on the commitments and liabilities that UNDP estimates it will make during 
the next semiannual period, unless otherwise agreed by ADB and UNDP. With respect to 
procurement,  funds  transferred  by  ADB  to  UNAIDS  via  UNDP  (India)  shall  be  used  for 
procurement of equipment, goods, and services from eligible ADB member countries only (para. 
22[b], MOU), which will be accomplished under open and competitive selection (para. 23[b], 
MOU). All procurement of goods, equipment, and services using funds transferred by ADB to 
UNAIDS  for  the  TA  shall  be  carried  out  using,  and  in  accordance  with,  UNDP  policies, 
procedures, and documentation for the procurement of goods, equipment, and services as set 
out in the UNDP Procurement User Guide and as agreed upon under the MOU. UNAIDS will 
select  and  subcontract  designated  subnational  partners  (e.g.,  national  research  institute, 
training  institute,  and  service  delivery  NGOs),  applying  the  selection  criteria  set  forth  in 
Supplementary Appendix A. The organization chart of the NACO North East Regional Office in 
Assam is in Supplementary Appendix B. 
 
18.  The  UNAIDS  Secretariat  will  produce  an  inception  report  2  months  after  the 
commencement of services, and submit biannual technical and financial progress reports and a 
final report to ADB (with copy to the Ministry of Development of the North East Region, NACO, 
State Public Works Department, State Department of Women and Child Development, and 
State Social Welfare Department). The final report by UNAIDS will include comments provided 
by NACO and ADB within 30 days after the final tripartite meeting. The report will be submitted 
in English and should include technical analyses supported by data, with administrative and 
other details in appendixes. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,475,000  to  the 
Government of India to be financed on a grant basis by the Cooperation Fund for Fighting 
HIV/AIDS in Asia and the Pacific for Addressing Social and Health Issues Associated with Road 
Improvement in Selected North Eastern States (Assam, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Manipur, and 
Nagaland), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS 
 
1.  The National AIDS Control Organization (NACO)-supported north eastern state plans 
are being developed. Once finalized, the United Nations (UN) agency-specific and joint agency 
strategies and work plans will be finalized based on agencies‘ mandates and comparative 
advantages, under the UN Joint Initiative for the North East. The activities supported by this 
technical  assistance  (TA)  will  be  integrated  within  the  UN  joint  initiative  and  implemented 
through  the  NACO  Regional  Office  in  Guwahati. The  Joint  United  Nations  Programme  on 
HIV/AIDS  (UNAIDS)  Secretariat  will  be  responsible  for  the  overall  coordination  of  the  TA 
activities, support the NACO North East Regional Office, and mobilize UN expertise in a timely 
manner.1 
 
2.  Administrative arrangements. On behalf of the UNAIDS Secretariat, an administrative 
arrangement will be signed between the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and United Nations 
Development  Programme  (UNDP)  through  the  UN  Resident  Coordinator‘s  Office  (UNRC). 
Disbursement and procurement arrangements will be in accordance with the modalities set out 
in  the  Memorandum  of  Understanding  between  the  ADB  and  the  UNDP,  Appendix  B, 
Administrative Arrangements for ADB-UNDP Project Cooperation signed on 23 July 2007 and, 
more specifically, Appendix B [ADB-UNDP memorandum of understanding (hereafter, MOU)]. 
 
3.  The agreement will outline the roles and responsibilities, funds flow, accountability, and 
reporting arrangements. The UNAIDS Secretariat will be responsible for the overall execution of 
the TA and will be the designated TA coordinator. UNDP will be the funds manager for the TA 
and will be responsible for the channeling of funds to implementing UN organizations involved in 
the implementation of TA activities through the UN pass-through funding mechanism.2 
 
4.  Accountability. The programmatic and financial accountability of the TA activities rests 
with the implementing UN organizations that are managing their respective components of the 
TA.  Where  UNDP  is  also  the  implementing  UN  organization,  like  the  other  agencies,  its 
standard accountability for its program resources applies for the portion of the funding that it is 
implementing. The TA coordinator reports on its performance to the UNRC. 
 
5.  Reporting responsibility. The reporting responsibility for administrative and financial 
reporting  rests  with  the  TA  coordinator.  The  TA  coordinator  prepares  consolidated 
administrative/financial and technical reports and submits them to ADB through the UNRC. 
Reports will be submitted to ADB in draft form 2 weeks before the date of each of the three TA 
consultations—with  attached  draft  technical  reports—and  in  final  draft  form  2  weeks  upon 
completion of the TA consultations, based on the schedule in Table A2.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consultant team will be composed of (i) team leader (36 person-months), to be based 
at the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) North East Regional Office; (ii) national 
research institute (9 months, component 1); (iii) policy and legal specialist (3 person-months, 
component 2); (iv) national training institute (12 months, components 3–4); and (v) service 
delivery nongovernment organizations (NGOs) (24 months each, 1 per state; components 5–6). 
 
A.  Team Leader (national, 36 person-months) 
 
2.  The team leader (gender and HIV specialist) will be recruited as an individual consultant 
and liaise  with the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS via NACO‘s North East 
Regional Office throughout project implementation. At project onset, he/she will develop a viable 
work plan consistent with the Joint United Nations (UN) Support Plan for HIV and AIDS India 
2007–2011  and  the  Joint  UN Work  Plan  for Capacity  Building, Technical  Assistance,  and 
Program  Support  for  India  States  of  the  North  East1.  The  team  leader  will  have  overall 
responsibility for the substantive direction of the technical assistance (TA), field activities and 
direct interventions, and for preparing relevant outputs summarizing TA findings, promising 
practices, and recommendations. He/she will have a master‘s degree in political science, social 
sciences,  or  public  health,  with  at  least  10  years  of  significant  prior  experience  and 
demonstrated  skills  and  expertise  in  HIV  project  design  and  management,  the  grassroots 
realities of HIV civil society organization operations, preferably in the North East, and have 
consulted for development partners. The team leader will be based at the North East Regional 
Office and be responsible for: 
 
(i)  finalizing  the  detailed  methodology  for  the  TA-supported  research,  capacity 
development,  and  direct  interventions,  and  prioritizing  areas  for  focused 
interventions; 
(ii)  ensuring  regular  interaction  with  the  research  institute,  training  institute(s); 
economic operators, state civil society organizations, and trade unions involved 
in TA implementation; 
(iii)  liaising  with  Asian  Development  Bank  headquarters  and  the  India  Resident 
Mission to ensure regular update of the TA team on any changes in the selection 
of roads and/or implementation of road construction under the proposed North 
Eastern  State  Roads  Investment  Program,  which  may  impact  the  TA 
implementation; 
(iv)  organizing events and submitting relevant administrative, financial and technical 
reports,  and  research  outputs  to  the  Joint  United  Nations  Programme  on 
HIV/AIDS Secretariat for distribution to relevant UN system organizations and the 
ADB (Appendix 2, Table A2). 
 
B.  National Research Institute (9 months) 
 
3.  The national research institute will have expertise in carrying out HIV-related research, 
demonstrated  by  their  publications  (in  national  and  English  languages)  and  the  range  of 
expertise of its staff. The research coordinator will have a postgraduate university degree, 
preferably in applied social sciences, significant prior experience with survey research and other 
social  science  research  tools  and  methodologies,  and  be  familiar  with  HIV  issues  and 
                                                
1  UNAIDS. 2007. Joint UN Support Plan for HIV and AIDS India 2007-2011. Delhi.; UNAIDS. 2006. UN Joint Work 
Plan Capacity Building, Technical Assistance and Program Support for India States of the North East. Delhi.

12  Appendix 4 
 
 
operations in India. He/she will take the lead in designing survey and related research tools and 
writing up the results of that research. 
 
4.  The research institute will be responsible for activities under component 1: (i) developing 
the monitoring and evaluation framework to be adopted in the project; (ii) conducting the HIV 
risk assessment; (iii) conducting the capacity needs assessment; and (iv) preparing baseline 
surveys, impact-oriented surveys (targeting both intervention and control groups), end-of-project 
surveys, and qualitative interviews and discussions, which will be used in the implementation of 
the TA. 
 
5.  Bio-behavioral  HIV  surveys  will  be  carried  out  at  the  start  of  construction,  during 
construction, and after project completion. They will (i) provide baseline data and information; 
(ii) establish  an  early  warning  system  for  monitoring  the  increased  level  of  STI  and  HIV 
incidence; (iii) provide relevant information on a set of agreed output and impact indicators in 
line with NACO‘s strategic information management system; (iv) assess project impacts; and (v) 
produce a research paper on the links between HIV, roads, and risky behavior.2 
 
C.  Policy and Legal Specialist (national, 3 person-months) 
 
6.  The policy and legal specialist will be recruited as an individual consultant. He/she will have 
a graduate university degree in law, government, or political science and at least 5 years of 
relevant professional work experience. This component will involve the assessment of (i) policy 
commitments to gender and HIV/AIDS at central level and their incorporation in state-specific 
infrastructure sector strategies, master plans, and regulatory frameworks for public investments, 
construction,  contractor  accreditation,  mobile/migrant  population,  workplace,  and  labor 
environment; (ii) existing government agencies, economic operators, and community-based 
organizations  involved  in  HIV  prevention;  (iii)  transport  and  construction  companies‘  and 
associations‘  response  to  the  epidemic;  and  (iv)  existing  arrangements  and  public–private 
partnership modalities for the mitigation of health and other social risks inherent in infrastructure 
development. 
 
D.  National Training Institute (12 months) 
 
7.  The national training institute will develop the capacity of selected state NGOs, community-
based  organizations,  and  people  living  with  HIV  (PLHIV)  organizations  involved  in  HIV 
preventive  education  and  behavior  change  in  the  project  area.  Indicatively,  capacity 
development program inputs will involve training, exposure visits, ―handholding‖ or mentoring, 
and knowledge- and experience-sharing workshops. State NGOs will be able to implement 
activities under components 4–5 upon completion of the first phase of the training. 
 
(i)  First phase. Technical aspects of HIV prevention and care. This will include 
basic information on HIV and STIs, HIV testing, and counseling; peer education 
and community outreach; condom programming; targeted interventions for most 
at-risk groups; gender and vulnerability aspects of STIs/HIV; behavior change 
communication and development of information, education and communications 
(IEC) material, and management of STIs (50 participants per session, 1 session 
per month, 3-month period).3 
                                                
2  Opportunities will be explored to collaborate with development partners such as the World Bank on the proposed 
research paper. 
3  NGOs will be eligible to implement activities under components 4–5 upon completion of the first phase of the 
training.

Appendix 4  13 
 
(ii)  Second  phase.  NGO  management  techniques.  This  will  include  structures, 
policies, and procedures; good governance and decision-making; project design 
and management; human and financial management systems (tracking, reporting, 
and accounting); management information systems; critical analysis and strategic 
thinking; external relations and partnership building; resource mobilization (50 
participants per session, 1 session per quarter, 9-month period). 
 
E.  Service Delivery Nongovernment Organizations (120 months) 
 
8.  Service delivery NGOs will be responsible for design and implementation, in consultation 
with state PLHIV networks, components 5 (selected HIV interventions) aimed at mitigating the 
STI/HIV risks and impact in relation to infrastructure operations and developing the capacity of 
PLHIV self-help groups. 
 
9.  NGOs will support the contractors in carrying out participatory HIV prevention programs 
that aim to change behavior, promote early diagnosis, and assist affected individuals in the 
campsites and local communities throughout the contract. This will involve (i) recruitment of 
qualified health personnel; (ii) training and mobilization of HIV educators, including at least 50% 
HIV-positive people; (iii) conducting regular participatory HIV education to all the site staff and 
labor and to the immediate local communities; (iv) distributing condoms to site staff and laborers, 
through professional social marketing organizations; and (v) providing access to HIV information 
and referral services for other illnesses. 
 
10.  NGOs will also design and implement, in consultation with state PLHIV networks, a 
range  of  appropriate  livelihood  and  self-employment  training  for  local  PLHIV—based  on 
identified good practices—and include vocational training and economic rehabilitation measures.
